Polymerization of ethylene plays a pivotal role in the production of polyethylene, a widely used polymer. Efficient catalysts are crucial for enhancing the polymerization process and improving polymer properties. In this study, we employ density functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate the influence of the SiO2 surface by linker approach on the reactivity of ethylene polymerization catalyzed by the Ni-α-imine ketone-type complex. Our results unveil valuable insights into molecular interactions and mechanistic aspects driving the improved polymerization process in good agreement with experimental findings. We identify strong hydrogen bonds as the key factor facilitating the favorable binding of the molecular catalyst with the SiO2 surface, involving a chemisorption process. Furthermore, we find that chain initiation is a rate-determining step for the molecular catalyst, whereas chain propagation is rate-determining for the supported catalyst, aligning with experimental differences in ethylene polymerization activity. Energy decomposition analysis reveals the dominant roles of electrostatic and orbital interactions in stabilizing both catalysts. Notably, the chemisorbed catalyst exhibits enhanced catalyst-ethylene interaction, while steric effects primarily impact the reactivity of the homogeneous catalyst. The supported catalyst exhibits a higher propagation barrier due to a late transition state. Additionally, the heterogeneous catalyst demonstrates superior ethylene uptake and thermal stability across a range of temperatures in agreement with the experimental data. These findings offer guidance for future experimental designs, emphasizing the importance of heterogenization and catalyst-ethylene interaction for enhancing ethylene polymerization processes. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ethylene polymerization SiO2-supported catalyst Heterogeneous catalyst Nickel catalyst DFT calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polyolefins are the most common and widely used synthetic polymers for industry and daily life products due to their excellent properties, including chemical stability, corrosion resistance, flexibility, and low cost, representing almost 180 million tons of plastics produced worldwide [1]. An important point to note is that despite ecological concerns regarding its use, polyolefins have higher performance and energy efficiency than biopolymers [2]. Likewise, the production of biopolymers implies a relatively large environmental impact, which even counteracts its ecological design. Polyethylene (PE) is the most versatile and cheapest polyolefin, with different commercial microstructures; (i) low-density polyethylene (LDPE); (ii) high-density polyethylene (HDPE), and (iii) linear low-density polyethylene (LLDPE), which differ in their chemical and physical properties and therefore in their applications. The discovery of novel and efficient transition-metal catalyzed systems has become the main research topic in this field [3]. A desirable catalyst must provide (i) high reaction activity, (ii) product selectivity, and (iii) recyclability, so achieving these three pillars would allow obtaining fast reaction rates, maximized product yield, and better use of this raw material in terms of efficiency and cost of the process. For instance, homogeneous transition-metal-based olefin polymerization catalysts have gained acceptance, but heterogeneous catalysts still dominate the industry [4–6]. The use of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) as heterogeneous catalysts has significantly increased in recent years since they have been considered a more efficient alternative for ethylene oligomerization/polymerization catalysis [7–11] with excellent catalytic activities. Likewise, the heterogenization of molecular catalysts with solid supports unifies these three fundamental characteristics [12–16]. Nevertheless, understanding their catalysis is complex due to their multisite nature. Therefore, heterogenizing molecular catalysts have attracted much attention because they combine successful homogeneous catalysts (high activity and selectivity) with surfaces (e.g., SiO2, TiO2, Al2O3, etc.), forming promising heterogeneous systems [12]. For example, the TiCl4 Ziegler-Natta molecular catalyst supported in MgCl2 surface by activating AlEt3 (triethylaluminum) is the most used catalyst for PE production at an industrial level [17] (Scheme 1 a). Nevertheless, several competing reactions lead to catalyst deactivation during ethylene polymer propagation. Nowadays, the great majority of the heterogeneous molecular catalysts are based on metallocene complexes of Zr [12,16,18,19] and Hf [15,18]. mediated by metal-bonding interactions with the solid support to produce HDPE on a large scale (Scheme 1b). Usually, these molecular catalysts requires oxide surfaces containing dehydroxylated oxide −OH groups to form covalent or non-covalent M-O interactions. When heterogenizing catalysts based on early transition metals is necessary to use strongly Brønsted acidic supports such as sulfated metal oxides (sulfated zirconium oxide; SZrO) because weakly Brønsted acidic supports such as SiO2 form M-O covalent interaction inactivating the polymerization process [12]. Sulfated metal oxide supports yield highly electrophilic adsorbate species, forming active heterogeneous catalysts for olefin hydrogenation and polymerization. In the case of complexes based on late transition metals, nickel-based olefin polymerization catalysts have seen rapid growth in the field due to their high catalytic efficiency (TOF∼ 7.0 × 106 g(PE)/mol(Ni)h) [20] comparable to many early transition-metal catalysts (Ti, Zr, or Cr) and their low cost making them more attractive alternatives than their high-cost palladium counterparts [21,22]. However, there has been no important commercialization due to the polyolefin industry preferring heterogeneous systems. The Brookhart-type Ni-α-diimine catalysts are interesting structures because they are easy to synthesize and modify, producing high molecular weight polyethylene with excellent activities (up to 1 × 107 g(PE)/mol(Ni)h) [23,24]. However, when this catalyst is heterogenized was initially reported with low activities (41 g/mmol catalyst‚h) at higher temperatures based on MAO (methylaluminoxane) bound to the SiO2 support [19] (Scheme 1a). To overcome this disadvantage, new methods to attach Ni-α-diimine catalysts onto support surfaces without a cocatalyst such as MAO were achieved by using an amino functionality in the Ni-α-diimine onto the MgCl2 support, obtaining better catalytic activities for ethylene polymerization (Scheme 1c) [25]. Similarly, Chen and co-workers [26] modified the structure of the imine ligand as shown in Scheme 2 , where one of the imine sites of the complex has an aryl substituent, which is perpendicular to the plane of the metal center, allowing the substituent to protect the axial position from the metal center effectively (Scheme 2b). The other side of the ligand can be modified by ketone or phosphine oxide. Both ligand sites are sterically open, allowing an efficient insertion of the monomer. These new catalysts are highly active in the polymerization and copolymerization of ethylene and do not require any cocatalyst, being an economical alternative and easy to manipulate experimentally. These catalytic systems involve pre-generated cationic nickel centers in the form of [Ni(allyl)]+ complexes. These pre-formed complexes have been demonstrated to display substantial activity in ethylene polymerization. Most interestingly, the ligand framework of Scheme 2b allows to heterogenized the molecular Ni-catalyst by installing a functional linker group (OH) (Scheme 2c), avoiding the use of any cocatalyst such as MAO [26]. Ni-OH@SiO2 catalyst exhibited an increased affinity with the solid support of silica by hydrogen-bonding-induced interactions between the linker group and the SiO2. Therefore, this approach facilitates mechanistic studies and the rational design of heterogeneous catalysts. Ni-OH@SiO2 showed greater thermal stability obtaining PE of high molecular weight (7.0 × 105 g/mol) even at 100 °C [26]. and producing molecular weights of much higher than one million (1.6 × 106 g/mol) compared to its homogeneous counterpart (Ni-OH) [26], which is probably due to increased steric effect from interactions between the solid support and the anchoring group. The ethylene polymerization activities were also very high in a range of 0.4×107–0.2×107 g(PE)/mol(Ni)h, as the temperature rises from 50 °C to 100 °C while Ni-OH exhibited very similar activities in a range of 1.4 × 107–0.1 × 107 g(PE)/mol(Ni)h at the same temperatures. However, the authors do not point to the reason for the difference in their catalytic performances, and many important mechanistic and structural-reactivity relationship details remain unclear [13,26]. In this paper, we attempted to answer why the presence of SiO2 surface improves the catalytic reactivity of the ethylene polymerization process. Answering this question will provide insights into the role of the Ni-α-iminoketone catalyst using a linker approach with the solid support of SiO2. We will explore by Density Functional Theory (DFT) key aspects of the Ni-catalyst with surface interaction, offering a unique opportunity to understand better some relevant aspects of surface chemistry in this field. 2 Computational methods All intermediates and transition state structures were optimized using the dispersion-corrected ω-B97XD functional [27], with the 6–31+G(d,p) [28]. basis set for all the atoms in the gas phase in Gaussian 16 [29]. In the case of heterogeneous systems, the calculations were performed at the same level of theory and considering a constrained geometry optimization, keeping the SiO2 surface fixed except for the top silanol (SiOH) and the siloxane (SiOSi) groups that interact with the anchoring groups of the molecular catalyst to avoid the silica model's deformation due to the size effect of the cluster. Conformational sampling of intermediates for homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts was carried out using the Conformers module in BIOVIA Materials Studio [30] by the random sampling search method, which is a stochastic procedure where the starting conformation is perturbed by randomly altering each set of dihedral angles. Then the most stable low-energy conformers were optimized using the same method in Gaussian 16. To facilitate the search for transition states, the nudged elastic band + saddlepoint-minimization (NEB-TS) method implemented in ORCA 5.0.1 [31] were performed to verify the connection between the intermediates by the searching of the minimum energy path (MEP) and the transition state connecting both minima. The NEB-TS calculations were performed at the same level of theory, computing ten intermediate images between the reactant and products. Then, the geometry of the obtained transition state were fully optimized in Gaussian16. Furthermore, vibrational frequency calculations were also performed to confirm the nature of the optimized structures as local minimums or transition states. Solvation energy corrections were calculated by single point energies with the SMD continuum solvation model [32] in toluene as solvent (ε = 2.37). In addition, reported Gibbs free energy profiles in solution include Truhlar's quasi-harmonic corrections [33], which were performed in GoodVibes [34] for all the stationary points using 100 cm−1 as the frequency cutoff, and applying thermal corrections at 298, 323, 353, and 373 K according to the experiment. To find the most stable adsorption conformations between the Ni-α-imine ketone catalyst with the SiO2 surface, the Adsorption Locator module in BIOVIA Materials Studio [35] was performed. This module uses the Monte Carlo-based simulated annealing method, in which the universal force field [36] was selected to calculate the intermolecular potential energy, fixing a number of 12 conformers. The six most stable conformers were fully optimized under the same level of theory in Gaussian16 and were analyzed by computing the interaction energies (ΔEint) of Ni-OH@SiO2 complexes according to the following equation: (1) Δ E i n t = E N i − O H @ S i O 2 − E N i − O H − E S i O 2 + Δ E B S S E Where the first term is the total energy of the relaxed system (Ni-OH@SiO2), and the next two are the unrelaxed energies of the isolated nickel catalyst (Ni-OH) and the cluster of SiO2, while ΔEBSSE is the correction for basis set superposition error (BSSE) [37], which is obtained via the counterpoise method in Gaussian 16. The analysis of these adsorption conformations (see Fig. 2) was carried out in the next section. Furthermore, adsorption energies (ΔEads) and Gibbs free energies (ΔGads) were also computed using Eq. (1). For these calculations, the relaxed energies of the isolated nickel catalyst (Ni-OH) and the cluster of SiO2 were considered (Table S1). On the other hand, ΔEint between the monomer and the catalysts was also computed in the transition states using the Absolutely Localized Molecular Orbital EDA (ALMO-EDA) [38] in Q-Chem 5.4 [39] ALMO-EDA method allows to dissecting the interaction energy into chemically meaningful terms such as electrostatic Coulombic interactions (ΔEelec), the orbital interactions (ΔEorb) between the catalysts and the monomer by interfragment charge transfer, and the intrafragment polarization energies, dispersion interactions (ΔEdisp), and the Pauli repulsion (ΔEpauli) by steric effects: (2) Δ E i n t = Δ E e l e c + Δ E o r b + Δ E d i s p + Δ E p a u l i Frontiers Molecular Orbitals were analyzed in some key intermediates and the ethylene monomer to characterize their ability to uptake. Moreover, the electronic population analysis will also be carried out for insight into the charge distribution on the Ni centers and some relevant atoms in the ligands using the CM5 atomic charges [40] in Multiwfn 3.7 software [41]. The steric effects were studied by geometric factors (bond distances, torsion, and bite angles), as well as the percent buried volume (Vbur%) [42,43], which is an indicator of the steric effects in the first coordination sphere of the metal center. These calculations were performed using the SambVca 2.1 program [43], considering a radius of 5.0 Å to accurately describe the steric effects of the ligands further away from the metal center. The intermolecular interactions between both catalysts and the ethylene monomer were characterized qualitatively by noncovalent interactions (NCI) in the framework of the Independent Gradient Model with the Hirschfeld partition (IGM) method [44] using Multiwfn 3.7. This method allows to identify the net of electron density attenuation due to interactions focusing on describing only the intermolecular regions among the fragments (δg inter) by color codes; red, strong repulsions; blue, strong attraction; and green, weak interactions. 2.1 Construction of the SiO2 cluster model Amorphous SiO2 surface is the most common support in heterogeneous catalysis because the thermal effects induce disordered structural morphology, which is difficult to determine. Therefore, from the numerous known SiO2 crystalline forms, we have focused on the α-quartz (α-SiO2) crystallographic model, which is the most stable silica phase at moderate temperatures and pressure. α-SiO2 model (Fig. 1a ) was obtained from Materials Project [45] with (001) crystalline orientation (Fig. 1b). In this case, a 2 × 2 supercell were used to build a slab model consisting of 12 molecular units with a thickness of 5.1 Å, on the basis of DFT calculations, using the Crystal17 package [46]. From this model a closed-shell finite cluster (Si12O36H26) has been designed according to Fig. 1b. This surface was truncated, satisfying the four valences of Si atoms coordinated to at least four oxygen atoms, while the valences of O atoms satisfied their valences with at least two Si atoms (SiO2; siloxane bridges), and all of the boundaries in SiO2 were ended by H atoms (silanols), according to Fig. 1b. This cluster model approach and their size was selected in this study because it accounts a distribution of different configurations of silanols and siloxane bridges, leading to results with a chemical meaning similar to larger clusters or the extremely computationally demanding periodic models with too large silica slabs, which facilitates the modeling of the adsorption interaction between the linker group of the molecular catalyst with the support [47,48]. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Adsorption conformations of the Ni-OH molecular catalyst on the SiO2 surface Since the mode and the strength of the adsorption of the Ni-OH molecular catalyst onto the SiO2 surface have not been revealed experimentally, the interaction energy (ΔEint) between the surface and the Ni-OH catalyst has been evaluated through Equation 1. Fig. 2 reveals different binding interactions between the OH linker group with the silica surface, confirming the experimental hypothesis that the adsorption interaction is associated with hydrogen bond interactions with the support. In all the cases, very strong hydrogen bonds are shown with distances in the range of 1.7–2.2 Å where one of the oxygen atoms of the silanol group on the SiO2 surface is delocalized around the hydrogen atom of the OH linker group (OH···OHSi), acquiring a type of "covalent component" indicating that the adsorption process might occur by chemisorption. It is well known that longer hydrogen bonds in the order of 3.5 Å are considered a pure dipole-dipole interaction, demonstrating that the linker group plays an important role in the heterogenization of the molecular catalyst. Furthermore, the negative interaction energy values for the A-F conformations indicate favorable adsorption interactions between the molecular catalyst and the SiO2 surface. The interaction of the linker group with the surface will be stronger when the orbital with the free electron pairs of the hydrogen bond acceptor have to be aligned quite well, which probably explains the different interaction energies for each adsorption conformation. In addition, our results suggest that the catalytic role of the silanol groups on the SiO2 surface are the key specific sites of interaction with the support since they interact with the linker group in all the adsorption conformations studied. In contrast, the siloxane bridges did not play any particular role. Interestingly, the interaction energy values show that the F adsorption conformation has the best adsorption conformation, with the silica surface showing the highest ΔEint value (−49.5 kcal/mol) compared to the other conformations (as well as concerning its feasibility and spontaneity of the adsorption process as is shown in Table S1), which exhibited less interaction energy values following this trend: A > D > C > E > B > F. The stronger interaction of the F conformation is influenced by the effect of two strong interacting SiOH groups, with an O···HOSi and an OH···OHSi silanol distances of 1.87 and 2.25 Å, respectively. These interactions are associated with the oxygen atom of the ketone moiety in the first coordination sphere and the hydrogen atom of the OH linker group in the second coordination sphere adopting a "lying" conformation on the SiO2 surface. This conformation confirms the chemisorption nature of the binding between the molecular catalyst and the silica surface, in which σ overlapping is exhibited between the linker group and the silanol group on the SiO2 surface (Fig. S1). Therefore, our results indicate that not only the anchoring group plays an important catalytic role but also the ketone unit of the first coordination sphere, which substantially favors the interaction with the silica surface as opposed to the A, B, D, and E adsorption conformations that only contemplate the interaction of the OH linker group with the support. In the case of C conformation, two interactions of the OH linker group are found, an H interaction with a silanol group on the SiO2 surface (1.77 Å) and an O interaction with another silanol group (1.85 Å), where their interaction energy is much lower than that of F conformation. At the same time, its adsorption and free energy are substantially lower by almost 10 kcal/mol, respectively (Table S1). 3.2 The role of the SiO2 surface on reactivity in the ethylene uptake In this section, we compare the ability of the molecular catalyst (Ni-OH) and the chemisorbed catalyst on the SiO2 surface (Ni-OH@SiO2) to uptake the ethylene monomer. Here we explore the origin of the reactivities in the Ni-OH and Ni-OH@SiO2 active species and their interaction with the monomer by steric and electronic parameters, as shown in Fig. 3 . The steric effects in the active species were analyzed by the percent buried volume (Vbur%), a powerful descriptor that quantifies the space occupied by the ligand in the first coordination sphere around the metal center, which indicates that the chemisorbed catalyst is sterically more demanding by 15% (Fig. 3a). Thus, since the ligands block the axial sites of the nickel center, ethylene could insert in an equatorial position in one possible less sterically hindered quadrant III, as is shown in Fig. 3a, which could probably increase the activation barrier for the ethylene insertion in this catalyst. In contrast, the homogeneous counterpart shows two possible more favorable quadrants (I and III) for ethylene insertion (see Fig. 3a). Furthermore, it is interesting to note that the greatest steric demand in both catalysts can contribute efficiently to longer chain forming by retarding the chain termination and producing polyethylene of higher molecular weight [26]. To understand the electronic factors that govern the ethylene insertion, orbital interactions between ethylene and the catalytic species were analyzed by the highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMOs) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs). Our results indicate that the HOMO of ethylene and the LUMO of both catalysts is the dominant combination since the HOMO-LUMO gap is smaller than the LUMO of ethylene with the HOMO of the catalytic species. Specifically, in Fig. 3b, we reported the most favorable orbital combinations for both catalysts, reaching a HOMO(ethylene)-LUMO(catalyst) gap of 5.5 eV (vs. 9.0 eV HOMO(catalyst)-LUMO(ethylene)) with the molecular catalyst and 5.3 eV (vs. 8.8 eV HOMO(catalyst)-LUMO(ethylene)) with the chemisorbed catalyst. These results indicate the higher chemical reactivity of the chemisorbed catalyst on SiO2, where for both molecular orbital combinations, the HOMO-LUMO energy gaps are more favorable concerning their homogeneous counterpart. In addition, the CM5 atomic charges show positive charges on the Ni centers for both catalysts (Fig. 3b). Specifically, the Ni-OH@SiO2 catalyst presents a more positive charge (0.37 vs. 0.35 e), which is induced by the more negative charge on the oxygen atom of the ketone moiety (−0.27 vs. −0.23 e) due to the hydrogen bonding with the SiO2 surface (O···HOSi; 1.87 A) reducing the electron density in the nickel atom, leading to a more favorable ethylene insertion. Notwithstanding, the stronger hydrogen bond in the Ni-OH@SiO2 catalyst is between the silanol group and the hydrogen atom of the OH linker group (Δe = 0.09), while the hydrogen bond formed with the oxygen atom of the ketone moiety with the silanol group is lower (Δe = 0.05) since the oxygen donor atom in the silanol group is more electronegative (−0.45 e) than the oxygen atom of the first coordination sphere (−0.27 e). Therefore, the formation of the hydrogen bond between the linker group and the SiO2 surface results in a greater shift of electron density, making both of them more attractive hydrogen bonding partners, which confirms the chemisorption nature of the binding (Fig. S1). In summary, the smaller HOMO-LUMO energy gap and the reduced charge on the Ni center benefit the ethylene coordination in the chemisorbed catalyst. 3.3 Ethylene polymerization reaction mechanism catalyzed by Ni-OH Here we focused on the chain initiation and propagation steps in the ethylene polymerization reaction catalyzed by the molecular Ni-OH complex. Fig. 4 shows the computed free energy profiles evaluated at the experimental temperatures (298, 323, 353, and 373 K) in toluene. The DFT calculations indicate that the ethylene uptake (Ni-OH + C2H4→ I1) occurs via σ-complex. It is well known that the allyl group has multiple binding modes on metal complexes, which can isomerize as σ (η1) complex from π (η3) complex (Fig. 5a ) [49–52]. To achieve the σ-complex, the isomerization can occur by rotation around the C-C bond. We have estimated the energy barrier of this isomerization process by nudged elastic band (NEB) path. The NEB path approximates the minimum energy path connecting a reactant and product by iteratively optimizing the linear interpolation between them (Fig. 5b), where a single transition state was identified for this process. This outcome indicates the formation of the σ-complex, with an associated electronic barrier estimated at approximately 26.2 kcal/mol. This is energetically unfavorable since it requires breaking two Ni-C bonds simultaneously. Then an easily accessible coordination site is formed for incoming ethylene molecule yielding the π-complex (I1 in Fig. 4) from which the polymerization cycle starts [52]. This process thermodynamically favorable by -16.1 kcal/mol at room temperature, decreasing this tendency as the temperature increases (-13.7–-11.0 kcal/mol). This result leads to the most stable conformer for the ethylene uptake, which is trans to the oxygen atom of the ketone moiety in the equatorial position, while the allyl group is orientated cis to the oxygen atom. Then, the subsequent ethylene insertion through the TS1 transition state structure reaches ΔGǂ ∼ 20 kcal/mol, and the formation of the insertion product P1 occurs exergonically from 323 K in a range of -1.0–-3.0 kcal/mol (Fig. 4), so whereas as the temperature increases, the formation of this product is slightly more favored. This result shows that according to the experimental results, the reaction yield at 373 K increases from 0.35 to 0.50 g after 30 min [26]. From P1, the second ethylene uptake occurs by a cis-coordination dissociating the agostic interaction from the nickel center to produce the I2 species. This process is thermodynamically favorable at 298 and 323 K by -1.6 and -0.7 kcal/mol, respectively. The chain propagation free energy barrier is 17.0 kcal/mol at room temperature, increasing to almost 19 kcal/mol upon reaching 373 K, leading to an exergonic β-agostic product formation (P2) by ∼ -14 kcal/mol on average. Our results agree with the experimental ethylene polymerization activities range from 1.6 × 107 to 0.1 × 107 g(PE)/mol(Ni)h at the same temperatures [26]. This insertion barrier is substantially lower than that of chain initiation, which is supported by the fact that I2 and TS2 structures maintain similar geometrical parameters in the α-imine ketone ring (N-Ni-O ∼ 79°). While the aryl rings are orientated in parallel alignment to the α-imine ketone ring and slightly further from the axial sites of the nickel center (Fig. 6 ), leading to π-π interactions and reducing the steric effects. The latter improves the activity and the chain growing, increasing the polyethylene molecular weight in agreement with the experiment. Moreover, we also performed a third ethylene insertion to get insights into how the catalytic activity and selectivity change at each of the temperatures evaluated. From P2, ethylene coordinates to the Ni center at the cis position forming I3 species, which is only slightly favorable at room temperature (ΔG° = -0.5 kcal/mol). This result agrees with the experimental findings, where the increase in temperature disfavors chain propagation. Then, the ethylene insertion has energy barriers of 16–18 kcal/mol, similar to the second ethylene insertion. Therefore, these results indicate that the chain initiation overcomes the higher energy barrier than the chain propagation, suggesting that the chain initiation is the rate-determining step, which can be directly related to the activity of the ethylene polymerization process for the molecular catalyst. 3.4 Ethylene polymerization reaction mechanism catalyzed by Ni-OH@SiO2 As in the previous section, we have also explored the chain initiation and propagation steps in the ethylene polymerization reaction catalyzed by the chemisorbed complex in order to have a clearer perspective of how the SiO2 surface improves the catalytic activity of the molecular Ni-OH catalyst. Fig. 7 shows that the ethylene uptake is also thermodynamically favorable by -12.9 kcal/mol at room temperature, decreasing as the temperature increases by almost 2.0 kcal/mol (Fig. 7). The allyl group is orientated cis to the oxygen atom of the ketone moiety in the less sterically demanding quadrant III (Fig. 3a), while the ethylene monomer is coordinated trans to the oxygen atom in a more steric quadrant IV according to Fig. 3a. In contrast to the molecular catalyst, the chemisorbed catalyst demonstrates less favorable ethylene coordination across all examined temperatures (Fig. 7). Intuitively, we can anticipate that the heightened steric effects on Ni-OH@SiO2 act to discourage the uptake of ethylene. Drawing from our preliminary analyses of analogous Nickel-allyl complexes [52], this discernible pattern is probably underpinned by the magnified steric and entropic impacts uniquely prevalent in the Ni-OH@SiO2 catalyst, distinguishing it from the Ni-OH counterpart. These influences trace their origins to the substantial bulkiness intrinsic to the Ni-OH@SiO2 catalyst, thereby imposing constraints upon the ethylene coordination process. However, favorable electronic properties on the Ni-OH@SiO2 catalyst allow a smaller HOMO(ethylene)-LUMO(catalyst) energy gap (5.3 eV vs. 5.5 eV) and a reduced charge on the Ni center (0.37 vs. 0.35 e) benefit the ethylene uptake in this catalyst. Then, it is found that, like the chain initiation process in Ni-OH catalyst, here the ethylene preferentially also inserts trans to the oxygen atom in the ketone moiety, requiring 22.8 kcal/mol at 298 K and increasing in 2.0 kcal/mol at 353 K and 373 K. In addition, the production of P1 is thermodynamically favorable in all the cases (∆G° ≈ -4.0 kcal/mol), leading to β-agostic interaction. Likewise, the second ethylene uptake from P1 to I2 occurs by cis-coordination concerning the oxygen atom of the ketone moiety, occupying the less sterically demanding quadrant III, according to Fig. 3a. This process is favorable for all the temperatures studied, which is an important difference concerning the homogeneous catalyst. Furthermore, the CM5 atomic charges of the Ni center in P1 species for Ni-OH and Ni-OH@SiO2 catalysts are 0.33 and 0.35 e, respectively, and the energy gaps HOMO(ethylene)-LUMO(P1-catalyst) are 5.2 and 5.5 eV, respectively, which accounts for the stronger interaction between the P1 species of the chemisorbed molecular catalyst and the ethylene molecule. A similar trend is observed for the ethylene uptake from P2 and P3 (Table S3). On the other hand, in contrast to the Ni-OH molecular catalyst, the chain propagation for the Ni-OH@SiO2 requires a greater barrier of 24.4 kcal/mol and is exergonic by -10.2 kcal/mol at room temperature. While at higher temperatures, it reaches a free energy barrier of around 25.0 kcal/mol, suggesting that chain propagation is the rate-determining step for the chemisorbed catalyst. Therefore, our results correctly predict the activity of these catalysts, where the activity for the SiO2-supported catalyst is lower (0.4 × 107 g(PE)/mol(Ni)h at 323 K) than its homogeneous counterpart under the same conditions (1.4 × 107 g(PE)/mol(Ni)h at 323 K) [26]. Furthermore, this result can be explained by the strong interaction of the molecular catalyst with the SiO2 surface, which reduces the rotation of the aryl rings, remaining the steric hindrance in the axial positions on the α-imine ketone ring. This fact leads to a lower kinetic facility in ethylene insertion, which explains the two higher barriers for the first and second insertion of ethylene. To quantify the increase in steric interaction, we have compared the percent buried volume (Vbur%) in the transition state structures of the homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts reaching for the TS1 structure 42% and 50%, respectively, and for the TS2 structure 39% and 56%, respectively, which agree with our hypothesis. Moreover, we suggest that the shorter C-C bond between the alkyl chain carbon atom and the ethylene carbon atom reaches 1.96 and (vs. 2.05 Å) 1.99 Å (vs. 2.08 Å) for TS1 and TS2, respectively, describing late transition states due to the bulky ligands. In addition, the larger C-C bond distances of the ethylene monomer reach 1.45 (vs. 1.41 Å) and 1.43 Å (vs. 1.41 Å) for the TS1 and TS2, respectively, which implies a greater stabilization of the monomer in the transition state. Energy decomposition analysis (EDA) was performed in the next section to get more insights into the origin of the reactivity of these species. Finally, we have explored a third ethylene insertion into the Ni-OH@SiO2 catalyst. From the P2 agostic product, ethylene uptake takes place at the cis-site to generate the I3 species (Fig. 7), and this process was only favorable at lower temperatures (298 and 323 K). Then, the ethylene insertion must overcome an energy barrier of ∼ 20.0 kcal/mol, which is higher than its homogeneous counterpart, while the reaction energies indicate that the formation of the P3 product is much more stable than for the homogeneous catalyst by almost 6.0 kcal/mol at room temperature and in the entire range of temperatures analyzed. This is in agreement with the experimental yields, which are higher for the supported catalyst (2.2–0.8 g vs. 0.7–0.5 g) [26]. 3.5 Origin of the reactivity in the homogeneous and supported SiO2 catalyst Although our results nicely reproduced the experimental trends, we performed energy decomposition analyses (EDA) for TS1 and TS2 in Ni-OH and Ni-OH@SiO2 catalysts to gain further insights into the activity difference between the homogeneous and the chemisorbed catalyst. Fig. 8 summarizes the EDA energy components for each species. The transition states TS1 and TS2 catalyzed with Ni-OH@SiO2 have much higher stabilizing ΔEint than TS1 and TS2 with Ni-OH by 14.2 kcal/mol and 11.3 kcal/mol, respectively. Interestingly, this result is because, in general, all the stabilizing factors (ΔEelec, ΔEorb, and ΔEdisp) are greater in Ni-OH@SiO2, overcompensating for the higher steric component (Δ∆Epauli= +62.1 kcal/mol in the TS1 and +63.2 kcal/mol in the TS2). The dominant factor stabilizing the transition states in both catalysts is the electrostatic energy (ΔEelec) followed by the orbital interactions with the monomer (ΔEorb), which predict that the transition states TS1 and TS2 are substantially more reactive in the chemisorbed species (Fig. 8). As a result, smaller amounts of the ΔEorb component in the Ni-OH transition states are observed (ΔΔEorb= +33.5 and +36.2 kcal/mol for TS1 and TS2, respectively). This result indicates that orbital interactions more strongly stabilize the transition states in the Ni-OH@SiO2 catalyst. Thus, to understand why orbital interactions might promote the ethylene insertion better in the chemisorbed catalyst, we found an interesting difference concerning the HOMO orbital in both catalysts. In the Ni-OH@SiO2 catalyst, the HOMO orbital is located in the ligands and the α-imine ketone ring (Fig. S2), suggesting its higher reactivity towards bonding with the monomer than the Ni-OH catalyst.0 On the other hand, compared to the Ni-OH-mediated transition states, the Ni-OH@SiO2-mediated transition states have stronger dispersion interactions, as is seen in green areas and quantitively by EDA calculations (Fig. S2). Similarly, the IGM analysis shows another factor potentially affecting ethylene insertion, the steric repulsions between the monomer and the catalyst. But only a smaller red area is also seen, indicating smaller steric repulsions with the monomer (Fig. S2). Although EDA calculations quantitatively indicate greater steric effects for Ni-OH@SiO2 (Fig. 8), describing kinetically less favorable transition states due to the bulky ligands (also predicted by Vbur%; Table S3). This fact might override the intrinsic electronic preference in the TS2 structure in this catalyst. In summary, EDA calculations reveal that electrostatic and orbital interactions are the dominant effects that stabilize the activity of both catalysts. These factors greatly enhance the stabilizing catalyst-ethylene interaction in the chemisorbed catalyst, while steric effects only promote the reactivity of their homogeneous counterpart. This factor increases the energy barriers in the supported catalyst by a kinetically less favorable process. 4 Conclusions We have presented a general computational study to elucidate the role of the SiO2 surface linker approach in the reactivity of the ethylene polymerization reaction catalyzed by the Ni-α-imine ketone-type complex. Our results indicate that the favorable binding of the molecular catalyst with the SiO2 surface is influenced by the chemisorption of the linker group with the SiO2 surface and strong hydrogen bonds. This result led to a smaller HOMO-LUMO energy gap and a more electrophilic Ni center benefitting the ethylene coordination in the chemisorbed catalyst. The mechanistic study indicates that the chain initiation and chain propagation were found as the rate-determining steps for the molecular catalyst and SiO2-supported catalyst, respectively, which are related to the activity of the ethylene polymerization process. In the case of the heterogeneous catalyst, ethylene insertion is slower, in agreement with the experimental results. On the other hand, our mechanistic study under the effect of the experimental temperature range (298–373 K) indicates that the ethylene uptake is greatly favored in the heterogeneous catalyst at all temperatures evaluated, predicting higher thermal stability of this catalyst according to the experimental data. Furthermore, energy decomposition analysis for the rate-determining transition states was quantitatively described, showing that electrostatic and orbital interactions are the dominant effects that stabilize the activity of both catalysts. These factors greatly enhance the stabilizing catalyst-ethylene interaction in the chemisorbed catalyst, while steric effects only promote the reactivity of their homogeneous counterpart. This factor increases the energy barriers in the supported catalyst by a kinetically less favorable process. We expect our results revealed in this study can offer unique insights to guide future experimental designs of more effective heterogenization of molecular catalysts by tunning electrostatic and steric effects in the first and second coordination sphere, which are probably easier to modify experimentally. In this way, it is expected to improve the ethylene polymerization process's activity and the molecular catalyst's adsorption ability with the support. coredata.dc:description: Polymerization of ethylene plays a pivotal role in the production of polyethylene, a widely used polymer. Efficient catalysts are crucial for enhancing the polymerization process and improving polymer properties. In this study, we employ density functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate the influence of the SiO2 surface by linker approach on the reactivity of ethylene polymerization catalyzed by the Ni-α-imine ketone-type complex. Our results unveil valuable insights into molecular interactions and mechanistic aspects driving the improved polymerization process in good agreement with experimental findings. We identify strong hydrogen bonds as the key factor facilitating the favorable binding of the molecular catalyst with the SiO2 surface, involving a chemisorption process. Furthermore, we find that chain initiation is a rate-determining step for the molecular catalyst, whereas chain propagation is rate-determining for the supported catalyst, aligning with experimental differences in ethylene polymerization activity. Energy decomposition analysis reveals the dominant roles of electrostatic and orbital interactions in stabilizing both catalysts. Notably, the chemisorbed catalyst exhibits enhanced catalyst-ethylene interaction, while steric effects primarily impact the reactivity of the homogeneous catalyst. The supported catalyst exhibits a higher propagation barrier due to a late transition state. Additionally, the heterogeneous catalyst demonstrates superior ethylene uptake and thermal stability across a range of temperatures in agreement with the experimental data. These findings offer guidance for future experimental designs, emphasizing the importance of heterogenization and catalyst-ethylene interaction for enhancing ethylene polymerization processes.
coredata.dc:title: How does the SiO2-supported nickel catalyst improve the ethylene polymerization process? Insights from DFT studies
